algorithm
Class TestingFactory

java.lang.Object
  algorithm.TestingFactory

public class TestingFactory
extends java.lang.Object

This class provides some useful parts to test parts of the QMC algorithm.
The word "arbitrary" in the method names indicates that the monoms we work on can have arbitrary entries hence also merged entires "-" or 2.
The word "binary" in the method names indicates that we only work with binary monoms, ie. monoms which have only entries 0 or 1.

Author:
chrissy

testArbitraryPowersetSorting

public static void testArbitraryPowersetSorting()
tests the powerset-sorting with arbitrary monoms. These monoms can also have an merged entry 2 or "-"

testBinaryPowersetSorting

public static void testBinaryPowersetSorting()
tests the powerset-sorting with only binary monoms, ie. monoms have only entries of 0 or 1 and hence are binary monoms

createArbitraryRandomizedMonom

public static Monom createArbitraryRandomizedMonom()
Returns:
a monom with randomized entries between 0..2. Such monoms are called "arbitrary" monoms.

createBinaryRandomizedMonom

public static Monom createBinaryRandomizedMonom()
Returns:
a monom with randomized entries only 0 or 1. No deleted entries are produced.
Such monoms are called "binary" monoms.

createArbitraryRandomizedMonomList

public static MonomList createArbitraryRandomizedMonomList(int k)
Returns:
a monomList with k arbitrary randomized monoms

createBinaryRandomizedMonomList

public static MonomList createBinaryRandomizedMonomList(int k)
Returns:
a monomList with k binary randomized monoms

constructThePowerSet

public static MonomList constructThePowerSet()
construts all monoms (ie of length 5) from 00000 00001 00010 00011 ..... ..... 11100 11101 11110 11111

Returns:
saves the complete powerset in this list
